job_title: IT Help Desk Technician II in Portland, OR
pros:
Diverse, friendly staff (mostly). 
Chiropractic benefits
Nice campus
cons:
This is not a grudge review, as I willingly left the company for C l better pay and opportunities. 
The pay vs workload expectations is sub pass to industry average.


 There is a a severe lack of process and change management. Senior managers/VP’s will go around the process if given a “no” on something because it’s against policy or creates a security issue. 

If you question anything, you’re pretty much on the chopping block. They only value working drones that so as they are told, which does not benefit the overall business.

They tell you that you aren’t qualified for a newly created position, even though you hold necessary credentials and experience, but then will promote someone within too a director position with little experience, and no interview process.

job_title: IT Help Desk in Portland, OR
pros: Great coworkers and easygoing job but tough to progress.
cons: Limited by budget for what you can do in your role heavily and can be fired for anything.

review_title: HR not as helpful as hoped
pros: colleagues are great to work with.
cons: directors of certain programs are not the most qualified and can make issues difficult to navigate.

job_title: Doctor of Chiropractic in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: great place to work, especially for your first job
Most staff and faculty were easy to work/partner with to find forward-thinking solutions; fairly good benefit package - health, time off, flexible hours within reason.
cons:
Take a seat ... Favoritism appears to play a very significant role in whether you advance or are taken seriously, whether within your official, assigned duties or are making improvement recommendations. Bringing one's professional experience to the job was often undermined and managers would quite often side with the less-informed choices, feeling like you are thrown under the bus.

I saw great, growth potential for UWS in terms of technology and automation, however, whether from fear or lack of understanding, much effort seemed to placed on maintaining the status quo. Worse yet, active work often was pushed aside for a pet project regardless of value to either student nor UWS.

In terms of performance reviews, this seemed more of a check-box activity than a true desire to partner and design a roadmap for the individual. As in other organizations, reviews were more subjective than an objective measure of one's accomplishments or work quality.

Speaking of roadmap, strategic, technical, personal I would say we did not really have these - not to the point of being able to develop clear, annual objectives.
I haven't identified any cons at this time

review_title: Maintain all facilities for higher Education campus, project mgmnt, landscape, safety and security, environmental impact
job_title: Director of Facilities in Portland, OR
pros: Diverse work load, ability to communicate freely with all from University president to receptionists, allowed to perform tasks creatively, excellent working relationship with supervisor,
cons: Board of Directors is all alumni which lacks diversity for making impactful long range decisions, especially where facilities and areas outside of their area of expertise is concerned

pros: Friendly atmosphere; competent & professional colleagues; interesting & challenging work; good opportunities for professional development; good salaries & benefits; organization is committed to improving itself.
cons: Some operational processes and procedures need to be improved

job_title: Anatomy and Physiology Teaching Assistant in Oregon City, OR
cons: Not much opportunity for full time work.
